docs.lead_paragraph: Somer Chipman and Chasity Glass have achieved the kind of academic success in high school that is often a passport to membership in the National Honor Society. Yet neither of these 17-year-olds made the cut at Grant County High in Williamstown, Ky. Both are teen-age mothers, apparently a disqualifying factor for the selection panel. Its decision was misguided. Officially, the Grant County school system has been circumspect about the precise reasons for the exclusion. But fragmentary remarks on the public record suggest the admissions panel decided that sexually active teen-agers cannot be role models. By that standard one wonders what tests the committee would devise in the future to verify which candidates for induction into the honor society had perfect records of abstinence.

headline.main: Sex, Honor and Grade Point Averages

docs.abstract: Editorial says Grant County school system in Williamstown, Ky, made misguided and seemingly unlawful decision to disqualify two exemplary students from membership in National Honor Society because they are teen-age mothers; says two, Somer Chipman and Chasity Glass, are doing well in school in spite of their parental responsibilities, and any honor society chapter should be proud to count them as members; notes American Civil Liberties Union has filed lawsuit in their behalf (M)
docs.snippet: Somer Chipman and Chasity Glass have achieved the kind of academic success in high school that is often a passport to membership in the National Honor Society. Yet neither of these 17-year-olds made the cut at Grant County High in Williamstown, Ky....

docs.lead_paragraph: Long before Jacquelyn Mitchard won the equivalent of the literary trifecta, she led her life as a memoir in progress. She was a newly widowed mother of five whose daily dramas were so unnerving that at one point her best friend threatened to ''break up'' with her. Then came the lightning shock of an endorsement from Oprah Winfrey, who featured Ms. Mitchard on her television book club in October 1996, increasing the hardcover copies in print of her debut novel, ''The Deep End of the Ocean,'' from 100,000 to more than 915,000.

headline.main: Reality Returns for an Anointed Author

docs.abstract: Jacquelyn Mitchard, who experienced rush of popularity and commercial success after her debut novel, The Deep End of the Ocean, was endorsed by Oprah Winfrey, finds to her chagrin that vast majority of Winfrey's television audience seems to be snubbing her new novel, The Most Wanted; Mitchard photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two 17-year-old high school students who say they were denied membership in the National Honor Society because they were pregnant are planning to sue their school board in Federal court here on grounds of sexual discrimination. The American Civil Liberties Union, which is to file suit for the girls on Thursday, says it sees the case as a way to seek wider enforcement of Federal laws banning sex discrimination due to pregnancy in high school.

headline.main: Lawsuit on Sex Bias by 2 Mothers, 17

docs.abstract: Somer Chipman and Chasity Glass, both 17 and top students at Grant County High School in Williamstown, Ky, say they were denied membership in National Honor Society because they were pregnant and are planning to sue their school board on grounds of sexual discrimination; American Civil Liberties Union says it sees case as way to seek wider enforcement of Federal laws banning sex discrimination due to pregnancy in high school; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The move in Congress and state legislatures to require health plans to cover birth control (front page, Aug. 2) is long overdue. There was no rush by insurers to pay when the pill came along; 35 years later most still don't cover prescription contraception, and insured women consequently pay two-thirds more than men in out-of-pocket health care costs. The Viagra debate highlights the double standard in sexual responsibility. The readiness of insurers to pay for Viagra implies support for the sexual lives of men. On the flip side, insurers refuse payment for contraception, which is necessary to women's sexual lives. More sex with less access to contraceptives means more unwanted pregnancy. It is in everyone's interest to make contraception more accessible so that there are fewer unwanted pregnancies and less need for abortion. WENDY CHAVKIN , M.D. New York, Aug. 5, 1998 The writer is a board member of Physicians for Reproductive Choice and Health.

headline.main: Can U.S. Insure Medical Privacy?; In Everyone's Interest

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Wendy Chavkin says readiness of insurers to pay for Viagra while refusing to pay for contraception for women highlights double standard in sexual responsibility (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The move in Congress and state legislatures to require health plans to cover birth control (front page, Aug. 2) is long overdue. There was no rush by insurers to pay when the pill came along; 35 years later most still don't cover...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Pressure Growing to Cover the Cost of Birth Control'' (front page, Aug. 2): Impotence is defined in medical dictionaries as the inability of the male to achieve or maintain an erection. Usually, this is caused by a defect that can be remedied and thus should be considered a treatable condition. Pregnancy, on the other hand, is a normal outcome of sexual intercourse that is open to the possibility of new life. It is never an abnormality.

headline.main: Can U.S. Insure Medical Privacy?; Viagra vs. the Pill

docs.abstract: Letter from Judie Brown, president, American Life League, prompted by Aug 2 article, says health insurance companies that cover Viagra, which can improve treatable condition, should not be asked to cover contraceptives, which are man-made chemicals taken by women who fear getting pregnant (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seizing upon the celebrity of the male impotency pill Viagra, family planning groups are pressing lawmakers in Congress and the states on a long-ignored demand that employers cover the costs of contraception as a health benefit. They are confronting lawmakers with the inequity they see in some employers' covering Viagra while denying women help in avoiding unwanted pregnancies. Gloria Feldt, president of the Planned Parenthood Foundation of America, which has been leading the lobbying in Congress for birth control coverage, said, ''The groundswell is there.''

headline.main: PRESSURE GROWING TO COVER THE COST OF BIRTH CONTROL

docs.abstract: Family planning groups, seizing upon celebrity of male impotency pill Viagra, are pressing lawmakers in Congress and the states on long-ignored demand that employers cover costs of contraception as a health benefit; they are confronting lawmakers with inequity they see in some employers' covering Viagra while denying women help in avoiding unwanted pregnancies; Planned Parenthood Foundation of America president Gloria Feldt has been leading lobbying in Congress for birth control coverage; Maryland was first state to mandate coverage of prescription contraceptives in workers' health insurance plans, approving bill in April; at least a dozen other states are weighing similar measures; US Senate and House have approved provisions, attached to appropriations bills, that would require Federal Government to offer all commonly prescribed forms of contraception to its 2.4 million employees who have health insurance; appropriations bills have yet to be considered (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The bulletin out of Beth Israel Medical Center yesterday morning was intriguingly incomplete. ''At least'' five sets of twins, the notice read, had been born there in the last 24 hours. The wording raised two possibilities: either doctors there had no idea exactly what was going on, or a statistically improbable occurrence was becoming even more so. In fact, set No. 6 was on its way by early afternoon, when a small army of doctors, nurses and public relations people greeted reporters with the vitals: more twins than had ever been born in so short a time at the hospital had blinked their wrinkled way into the world, starting at 7:40 A.M. Thursday. Half were the result of fertility treatments. Four of the 12 parents were lawyers. One father was a mailman. (''So both he and his wife deliver -- hah, hah, hah!'' one of the public relations people said.)

headline.main: United in Birth, 12 Twins in 30 Hours

docs.abstract: Six sets of twins are born at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City in thirty hours; photo of two sets (S)
